case_name: Legal Representatives of Late Karam Chand Thapar v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1374 and 2146 to 2149 of 1970 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1374 and 2146 to 2149 of 1970.

facts.text: Appeals from judgments and order dated July 30, 1963 and February 11, 1965 of the Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgments and order dated July 30, 1963 and February 11, 1965 of the Calcutta High Court

facts.text: High Court judgments in Income-tax Reference No. 48 of 1959 and 69 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: in Income-tax Reference No. 48 of 1959, and 69 of 1961 respectively.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Hegde, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Hegde, J.

facts.text: Appeals filed by legal representatives of Late Karam Chand Thapar, the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: All these appeals by certificate are filed by the legal representatives of Late Karam Chand Thapar who was the assessee in this case.

facts.text: Karam Chand Thapar died after the assessments were made.

anchor.surface_text: He died after the assessments were made.

facts.text: Assessment years concerned: 1949-50, 1950-51, 1951-52, 1952-53 and 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment years with which we are concerned in these appeals are 1949-50, 1950-51, 1951-52, 1952-53 and 1953-54.

facts.text: Late Karam Chand Thapar made certain cash gifts to his wife Smt. Mohini Thapar.

anchor.surface_text: Late Karam Chand Thapar made certain cash gifts to his wife Smt. Mohini Thapar.

facts.text: From out of those gifts, Smt. Mohini Thapar purchased certain shares and invested the balance amount.

anchor.surface_text: From out of those gifts, she purchased certain shares and the balance amount she invested.

facts.text: The shares earned dividends and the investments yielded interest.

anchor.surface_text: The shares earned dividends and the investments yielded interest.

facts.text: Interest realised and dividends earned were included in the income of Karam Chand Thapar for the assessment years.

anchor.surface_text: The interest realised and the dividends earned were included in the income of Karam Chand Thapar for the purpose of assessment in the assessment years mentioned earlier.

facts.text: The assessee objected to the inclusion of that amount in his income.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee objected to the inclusion of that amount in his income.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held that dividends and interest were liable to be included in the assessee's income.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer held that they were liable to be included in the income of the assessee.

facts.text: Decision of Income-tax Officer upheld by Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: That decision was upheld by- the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Tribunal upheld the order of the Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: On a further appeal, taken by the assessee to the Tribunal the Tribunal upheld the order of the Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Question referred to High Court under section 66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 at instance of assessee for 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter at the instance of the assessee, the question set out below was submitted to the High Court under section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, in respect of the assessment year 1949-50

facts.text: Income of Rs. 21,225 derived from deposits and shares held by assessee's wife Smt. Mohini Devi Thapar.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and on the circumstances of the case, the income of Rs. 21,225 derived from deposits and shares held by the assessees wife, Smt. Mohini Devi Thapar was income from assets directly or indirectly transferred by the assessee to his wife within the meaning of Section 16(3) of the Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Similar questions referred for other assessment years.

anchor.surface_text: Similar questions were referred in respect of other assessment year.

facts.text: High Court answered questions in favour of the revenue.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered these questions in favour of the revenue.

facts.text: Assets transferred were gift of cash amounts made by assessee to his wife.

anchor.surface_text: The assets transferred in this case is the gift of cash amounts made by the assessee to his wife.

facts.text: Transfers were direct transfers of cash.

anchor.surface_text: The transfers in question are direct transfers. But those assets, as mentioned earlier, were invested either in shares or otherwise.

facts.text: In Prem Bhai Parakh case, assessee retired from firm on July 1, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, who was a partner in a firm having 7 annas share therein, retired from the firm on July 1, 1954.

facts.text: Assessee gifted Rs. 75,000 to each of his four sons, three minors.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, he gifted Rs. 75,000 to each of his four sons, three of whom were minors.

facts.text: Firm reconstituted from July 2, 1954, major son partner, minor sons admitted to benefits.

anchor.surface_text: There was a reconstitution of the firm with effect from July 2, 1954, whereby the major son became a partner and the minor sons were admitted to the benefits of partnership in the firm.

facts.text: In Prem case, Tribunal found capital invested by minors came from gift by assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal found that the capital invested by the minors in the firm came from the- gift made in their favour by their father, the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 3  a  iii  of the Act-the provision relevant for the purpose of these appeals reads thus In companyputing the total income of any individual for the purpose of assessment, there shall be included-  a  so much of the income of a wife or minor child of such individual as arises directly or indirectly-  i   ii  from assets transferred directly or indirectly to the wife by the husband otherwise than for adequate companysideration or in companynection with an agreement to live apart

anchor.surface_text: The companynection between the transfer of assets and the income must be proximate. The income in question must arise as a result of the transfer and number in some manner companynected with it. The ratio of that decision is inapplicable to the facts of the present case.

concepts.interpretation: Nexus between asset transfer and income must be proximate, not remote; applied to hold nexus present here (dividends/interest from gifted cash investments) unlike Prem Bhai (partnership benefits).
concepts.unlisted_description: For S.16(3), connection between transferred assets and income must be proximate (directly or indirectly arising)

anchor.surface_text: Here we are dealing with an income which has proximate company- nection with the transfer of the assets made by the assessee.

issues.text: The question is whether the department was entitled to include the dividends and interest in question in computing the taxable income of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the department was entitled to include the dividends and interest in question in computing the taxable income. of the assessee.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and on the circumstances of the case, the income of Rs. 21,225 derived from deposits and shares held by the assessee's wife, Smt. Mohini Devi Thapar was income from assets directly or indirectly transferred by the assessee to his wife within the meaning of Section 16(3) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and on the circums- tances of the case, the income of Rs. 21,225 derived from deposits and shares held by the assessees wife, Smt. Mohini Devi Thapar was income from assets directly or indirectly transferred by the assessee to his wife within the meaning of Section 16 3

issues.text: Whether before an income can come within section 16(3)(a)(iii) it must be an income directly arising from the assets transferred.

anchor.surface_text: According to him before an income can companye within section 16 3   a   iii  it must be an income directly arising from the assets transferred. In other words, he urged that only such income which can be said to have directly sprung from the assets transferred Can companye within the scope of section 16  3   a   iii .

issues.text: Whether the income that can be brought to tax under section 16(3)(a)(iii) must have a nexus with the assets transferred directly or indirectly.

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with the companytention of Dr. Pal that the income that can be brought to tax under section 16  3   a   iii  must have a nexus with the assets transferred directly or indirectly. But in this case the income with which we are companycerned has a nexus with the assets transferred.

issues.text: Whether the ratio of the decision in Commissioner of Income-Tax v. Prem Bhai Parakh is applicable to the facts of the present case.

anchor.surface_text: In support of his companytention Dr. Pal relied on the decision of this Court in Commissioner of Income-Tax, West Bengal III Prem Bhai Parakh and others 1 . The facts of that case are as follows The assessee, who was a partner in a firm having 7 annas share therein, retired from the firm on July 1, 1954. Thereafter, he gifted Rs. 75,000 to each of his four sons, three of whom were minors. There was a reconstitution of the firm with effect from July 2, 1954, whereby the major son became a partner and the minor sons were admitted to the benefits of partnership in the firm. The question was whether the income arising to the minors by virtue of their admission to the benefits of partnership in the firm companyld be included in the total income of the assessee under section 16  3   a   iv  a provision similar to section 1 6  3   a   iii  The Tribunal found that the capital invested by the minors in the firm came from the- gift made in their favour by their father, the assessee. This Court overruling the companytention of the revenue came to the companyclusion that the companynection between the gifts made by the assessee and the income of the minors from the firm was a remote one and it companyld number be said that income arose directly or indirectly from the asses transferred. Hence I income arising to the three minor sons of the assessee by virtue of their admission to the benefits of partnership in the firm companyld number  1  1970 77 I.T.R. p. 27. be included in the total income of the assessee. The ratio of the decision is found at page 30 of the report. This is what the Court observed in that case The companynection between the gifts mentioned earlier and the income in question is a remote one. The income of the minors arose as a result of their admission to the benefits of the partnership. It is true that they were admitted to the benefits of the partnership because of the companytribution made by them. But there is numbernexus between the transfer of the assets and the income in question. It cannot be said that that income, arose directly or indirectly from the transfer of the assets referred to earlier.

arguments.claim: Incomes realised as dividends from shares or interest from deposits are income indirectly arising from the direct transfer of cash gifts to the wife.

anchor.surface_text: Hence it was urged on behalf of the revenue that the incomes realised either as dividends from shares or as interest from deposits are income indirectly received in respect of the transfer of cash directly made.

arguments.court_reasoning: This contention of the revenue appears to be sound. That position clearly emerges from the plain language of the section.

arguments.claim: There is no nexus between the income earned and the transfer; income must directly arise from the transferred assets to fall under Section 16(3)(a)(iii).

anchor.surface_text: It was urged by Dr. Pal, learned counsel for the assessee that there is no nexus between the income earned and the transfer of the assets. According to him before an income can come within section 16 3   a   iii  it must be an income directly arising from the assets transferred.

arguments.court_reasoning: Unable to accept; otherwise 'arises directly or indirectly' would be redundant. Net includes income arising indirectly.

arguments.claim: Income under Section 16(3)(a)(iii) must have a nexus with assets transferred directly or indirectly.

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with the contention of Dr. Pal that the income that can be brought to tax under section 16  3   a   iii  must have a nexus with the assets transferred directly or indirectly.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: . Pal that the income that can be brought to tax under section 16  3

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed on principle, but nexus exists in this case.

arguments.claim: Ratio of Commissioner of Income-Tax v. Prem Bhai Parakh applies: nexus between gifts and partnership income to minors was remote, so not includible under similar provision.

anchor.surface_text: In support of his contention Dr. Pal relied on the decision of this Court in Commissioner of Income-Tax, West Bengal III Prem Bhai Parakh and others. The facts of that case are as follows...

arguments.court_reasoning: Ratio inapplicable; here income has proximate connection with transfer unlike remote nexus in Prem Bhai.

arguments.claim: Section 16(3) requires strict construction; income must arise directly or indirectly from transfer with proximate nexus.

anchor.surface_text: The connection between the transfer of assets and the income must be proximate. The income in question must arise as a result of the transfer and not in some manner connected with it.

arguments.claim: In this case, nexus is proximate as income from shares/deposits directly stems from gifted cash.

holdings.text: The incomes realised as dividends from shares or as interest from deposits are income indirectly arising from the direct transfer of cash to the wife and are includible under Section 16(3)(a)(iii).

anchor.surface_text: This contention of the revenue appears to be sound. That position clearly emerges from the plain language of the section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of Section 16(3)(a)(iii) covers income arising indirectly from directly transferred assets.

holdings.text: The expression 'arises directly or indirectly' in Section 16(3)(a) covers both direct and indirect arising income from transferred assets; only direct income is not required.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this contention as sound. Otherwise the expression as arises directly or indirectly in section 16 3 a would become redundant. The net cast by section 16 3 a iii includes not merely the income that arises directly from the assets transferred but also that arises indirectly from the assets transferred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejecting narrow interpretation to avoid redundancy in statutory language; net cast includes indirect income.

holdings.text: Income includible under Section 16(3)(a)(iii) must have a nexus with the transferred assets, and in this case such nexus exists.

anchor.surface_text: We are in agreement with the contention of Dr. Pal that the income that can be brought to tax under section 16 3 a iii must have a nexus with the assets transferred directly or indirectly. But in this case the income with which we are concerned has a nexus with the assets transferred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees nexus required but finds it present as income directly stems from gifted cash invested in shares/deposits.

holdings.text: For inclusion under Section 16(3), the connection between transfer of assets and income must be proximate.

anchor.surface_text: The connection between the transfer of assets and the income must be proximate. The income in question must arise as a result of the transfer and not in some manner connected with it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopting strict construction principle from precedents like Keshavlal Lallubhai Patel and Prem Bhai Parakh for artificial income provisions.

holdings.text: The ratio in Commissioner of Income-Tax v. Prem Bhai Parakh is inapplicable here as the nexus is proximate, unlike the remote connection in that case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing precedent on facts: proximate nexus via direct investment vs. remote via partnership admission.

holdings.text: The income of Rs. 21,225 derived from deposits and shares held by the assessee's wife was income from assets directly or indirectly transferred by the assessee to his wife within Section 16(3).

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and on the circumstances of the case, the income of Rs. 21,225 derived from deposits and shares held by the assessees wife, Smt. Mohini Devi Thapar was income from assets directly or indirectly transferred by the assessee to his wife within the meaning of Section 16 3  of the Income-tax Act. ... This contention of the revenue appears to be sound.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Section 16(3)(a)(iii) to facts: cash gifts directly transferred, reinvested generating indirect income with proximate nexus.

holdings.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of holdings upholding revenue's position on all assessment years.
